value.name: HMRC £2,000 warning for people born between these two dates
value.description: This week, HM Revenue and Customs issued an alert to explain how this could have come about. The government body said that anyone who was born between September 1, 2002, and January 2, 2011, could be in this situation as they were beneficiaries of the Child Trust Fund.

value.name: Jeremy Corbyn leads protesters in London calling for a ceasefire in Gaza - with 20,000 joining march, despite organisers claiming 'hundreds of thousands' would be demonstrating
value.description: Jeremy Corbyn (pictured) was seen at the front of the London protest surrounded by signs calling for peace before he made a speech imploring Rishi Sunak to call for a ceasefire.

value.name: Labour ditches radical reforms as it prepares ‘bombproof’ election manifesto
value.description: Plans to reform social care and House of Lords are trimmed as Keir Starmer’s party opts for caution ahead of vote

value.name: SNP-controlled Glasgow is pothole capital of Britain with Labour-led Edinburgh second
value.description: Across Britain, the Scottish capital Glasgow - run by an SNP -led minority council - had more than 9,700 potholes reported by residents over the past 17 years, less than a third of which have been repaired. Edinburgh has had less than a quarter of the 5,538 reported potholes being filled in since 2007, the data shows.

value.name: A crash course in British politics: How elections work (Week 1)
value.description: This week’s article will explain how British elections work, and hopefully will answer all your related questions.

value.name: Concern about class sizes over 30 in Lancashire schools amid claim of '£28m cut in spending power'
value.description: Lancashire schools with more than 30 pupils in some of their classes will be unable to reduce the headcount to “acceptable” levels because of insufficient funding, a leading teaching union official has warned.

value.name: Unite members picket University over pay dispute
value.description: Non-teaching staff across the University of Cambridge picketed outside Senate House yesterday (02/02), marking the last of three days of industrial action across the University. Striking workers were joined by multiple student societies as they called for pay negotiations to be re-opened.

value.name: Tens of thousands of street lights will be dimmed in one area of Greater Manchester to save money
value.description: Bolton Council is set to dim 37,000 of its 40,000 streetlights as part of cuts to balance its budget. The Labour run council’s financial plans for 2024/25 include a plan to ‘dim and trim’ the borough’s streetlights to save £450,000 a year.

value.name: Stormont: Michelle O'Neill makes history as nationalist first minister
value.description: Sinn Féin's Michelle O'Neill has made history after she was appointed Northern Ireland's first nationalist first minister. The DUP's Emma Little-Pengelly has been appointed deputy first minister. The return of power-sharing follows the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) ending its boycott over post-Brexit trade rules.

value.name: DAN HODGES: Could Gaza and the shadow of George Galloway prompt Rishi into a snap election?
value.description: The Tory MP leapt up and did a jig of joy around the House of Commons Strangers' Bar. 'Really? That's been confirmed?' he asked. 'Is George Galloway standing in Rochdale?'

value.name: Labour's deputy leader Angela Rayner outlines party's 'new deal for workers'
value.description: Ms Rayner says that the Labour Party wants to remove 'bogus self-employment' within 100 days of being elected, but without damaging the economy or business.

value.name: Relief for young people’s mental health
value.description: Dr Simon Opher, Dursley GP and Labour Party Parliamentary candidate has announced a dramatic shift in the availability of mental health counselling and mentoring for young people in the Stroud area.

value.name: We need a new revolution to undo Tony Blair's vandalism of UK traditions, says Daniel Pitt
value.description: The lingering presents of New Labour are still with us. The constitutional vandalism of Tony Blair’s legal, judicial and administrative revolution has to be tackled head on. If the problems of illegal migration and the woke culture running through our ...

value.name: How the UK profits from war
value.description: As allies look sorrowfully on at our underfunded and shrinking armed forces, Britain’s arms trade is making a killing, with billions of pounds of taxpayers’ money being handed to arms manufacturers that give investors rich returns.

value.name: Labour to back bankers’ bonuses: How the Left responded
value.description: Labour will not reinstate a cap on bankers’ bonuses if it wins the next general election, the shadow chancellor announced this week. Saying she wanted to be the ‘champion of a thriving financial services industry,’ Rachel Reeves said she had ‘no intention’ of re-establishing the cap.

value.name: Three top Tories set to lose seats as MPs to Labour – including Jacob Rees-Mogg
value.description: A number of well-known Tories are being confronted by a stark reality - and the likes of Jacob Rees-Mogg face a daunting prospect.

value.name: Voices: Angela Rayner will be Labour’s most powerful minister in government – Keir Starmer should watch out
value.description: COMMENT: The deputy Labour leader and champion of workers’ rights may be an unexpected titan in office, writes

value.name: North Staffordshire council orders ban on giving animals as prizes
value.description: Giving pets as prizes has been banned by a North Staffordshire council. From now on giving pets as prizes will be banned in Newcastle-under-Lyme on council owned land.

value.name: Devastating reason Kate Garraway wore husband Derek Draper's watch to his funeral
value.description: The presenter was with her children Darcey and Bobby as the family said their final goodbye's to a loving husband and father.

value.name: Action on sewage dumped at Stone sports facility
value.description: Stone Labour Party and Councillor Jill Hood have joined forces to demand that Severn Trent stop dumping raw sewage straight into a major River Trent sports facility.

value.name: Cashless society drive 'damaging for rural Norfolk'
value.description: The declining use of cash and closure of banks in Norfolk towns, is spelling trouble for businesses, charities and vulnerable people,

value.name: A view from Carolyn Thomas – Welsh Labour’s North Wales Member of the Senedd
value.description: Wrexham.com has invited the four North Wales Members of the Senedd to write a monthly column with updates on their work. You can find their updates – along with contributions from the Wrexham and Clwyd South MPs and MSs – here.

value.name: LISTEN: Christine Jardine on Any Questions

value.name: Welsh Labour leadership election: Difference without division?
value.description: Labour’s leadership election rules have changed a lot from the days when trades unions welded block votes - when Unite backed Vaughan Gething last week it was welcome support for his campaign, but individual members can vote for whomever they choose.

value.name: Rayner denies confusion over Labour’s green pledge
value.description: Angela Rayner, Labour’s deputy leader, raised further questions about her party’s pledge to invest £28 billion in green energy when she said it could not be bound by an “arbitrary number”.

value.name: ‘Abandoned by the Conservatives’ - insiders say Wellingborough Tory by-election campaign is struggling to attract top-level support
value.description: The Times asked ‘Where’s Helen’ in an eviscerating sketch after they visited Wellingborough. And the final insult was an astonishing piece written by Conservative Home, a website set up in support of the Tory party which offers news, analysis and comment on internal goings-on.

value.name: Tata Steel begins formal 45-day consultation over plans for Port Talbot plant
value.description: Tata Steel has started a formal 45-day consultation on its restructuring which is set to lead to thousands of job losses. The company is planning to shut down blast furnaces at its plant in Port Talbot, south Wales, and switch to a more environmentally friendly way of producing steel.

value.name: ‘No-one, especially the Tories, is laughing at us now,’ says Reform leader
value.description: In an interview with i, the Reform Party leader says his 'medium-term' plan to take the Tories' place as the threat from the right to Labour

value.name: Bomb explodes outside ministry in Athens, no injuries
value.description: An explosive device went off outside Greece's labour ministry in central Athens early on Saturday but caused no injuries, Greek police said. value.name: Hartlepool Council scraps plans to reduce CCTV coverage after new funding found
value.description: Hartlepool Council planned to reduce the hours CCTV coverage would be monitored but now this has been scrapped due to new funding.

value.name: Ontario workers rally against Ford’s corruption, closures and cost-of-living crisis
value.description: NIAGARA FALLS, Ontario, Feb. 03, 2024 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Hundreds of trade union and community members, including health care and education workers, joined a rally organized by the Ontario Federation of Labour (OFL) during the Ontario PC Party’s 2024 ...

value.name: Michelle O'Neill appointed Northern Ireland's first nationalist first minister
value.description: Sinn Féin's Michelle O'Neill makes history after she is appointed Northern Ireland's first nationalist first minister.

value.name: ‘Anyone but Peter Bone’: voters turn to Labour and Reform UK as Wellingborough byelection nears
value.description: While Labour is favourite to snatch the Northamptonshire seat from the Tories, Sunak’s party faces a battle even to take second place, if local opinion is anything to go by

value.name: DAN HODGES: Could Gaza and the shadow of George Galloway prompt Rishi into a snap election?
value.description: The Tory MP leapt up and did a jig of joy around the House of Commons Strangers' Bar. 'Really? That's been confirmed?' he asked. 'Is George Galloway standing in Rochdale?'

value.name: Labour's deputy leader Angela Rayner outlines party's 'new deal for workers'
value.description: Ms Rayner says that the Labour Party wants to remove 'bogus self-employment' within 100 days of being elected, but without damaging the economy or business.

value.name: Relief for young people’s mental health
value.description: Dr Simon Opher, Dursley GP and Labour Party Parliamentary candidate has announced a dramatic shift in the availability of mental health counselling and mentoring for young people in the Stroud area.

value.name: We need a new revolution to undo Tony Blair's vandalism of UK traditions, says Daniel Pitt
value.description: The lingering presents of New Labour are still with us. The constitutional vandalism of Tony Blair’s legal, judicial and administrative revolution has to be tackled head on. If the problems of illegal migration and the woke culture running through our ...

value.name: How the UK profits from war
value.description: As allies look sorrowfully on at our underfunded and shrinking armed forces, Britain’s arms trade is making a killing, with billions of pounds of taxpayers’ money being handed to arms manufacturers that give investors rich returns.

value.name: Labour to back bankers’ bonuses: How the Left responded
value.description: Labour will not reinstate a cap on bankers’ bonuses if it wins the next general election, the shadow chancellor announced this week. Saying she wanted to be the ‘champion of a thriving financial services industry,’ Rachel Reeves said she had ‘no intention’ of re-establishing the cap.

value.name: Three top Tories set to lose seats as MPs to Labour – including Jacob Rees-Mogg
value.description: A number of well-known Tories are being confronted by a stark reality - and the likes of Jacob Rees-Mogg face a daunting prospect.

value.name: Voices: Angela Rayner will be Labour’s most powerful minister in government – Keir Starmer should watch out
value.description: COMMENT: The deputy Labour leader and champion of workers’ rights may be an unexpected titan in office, writes

value.name: North Staffordshire council orders ban on giving animals as prizes
value.description: Giving pets as prizes has been banned by a North Staffordshire council. From now on giving pets as prizes will be banned in Newcastle-under-Lyme on council owned land.

value.name: Devastating reason Kate Garraway wore husband Derek Draper's watch to his funeral
value.description: The presenter was with her children Darcey and Bobby as the family said their final goodbye's to a loving husband and father.

value.name: Action on sewage dumped at Stone sports facility
value.description: Stone Labour Party and Councillor Jill Hood have joined forces to demand that Severn Trent stop dumping raw sewage straight into a major River Trent sports facility.

value.name: Cashless society drive 'damaging for rural Norfolk'
value.description: The declining use of cash and closure of banks in Norfolk towns, is spelling trouble for businesses, charities and vulnerable people,

value.name: A view from Carolyn Thomas – Welsh Labour’s North Wales Member of the Senedd
value.description: Wrexham.com has invited the four North Wales Members of the Senedd to write a monthly column with updates on their work. You can find their updates – along with contributions from the Wrexham and Clwyd South MPs and MSs – here.

value.name: LISTEN: Christine Jardine on Any Questions
value.description: Christine Jardine was on Any Questions last night along with Ann Widdecombe (representing the Reform Party), Thangam Debonnaire and Sir Robert Buckland. She travelled to Bridgwater in Somerset. The first question was on whether we should have closer relations with the EU,

value.name: Welsh Labour leadership election: Difference without division?
value.description: Labour’s leadership election rules have changed a lot from the days when trades unions welded block votes - when Unite backed Vaughan Gething last week it was welcome support for his campaign, but individual members can vote for whomever they choose.

value.name: When Glasgow made history by hosting the Scottish Parliament
value.description: Twenty-four years ago the Scottish Parliament abandoned Edinburgh for Glasgow for a few weeks. "We are creating history", said

value.name: Mums go to Iceland - but the executive chairman of the company, which began in Shropshire, has gone to Labour.
value.description: Mums go to Iceland - but the executive chairman of the company, which began in Shropshire, has gone to Labour.

value.name: Rayner denies confusion over Labour’s green pledge
value.description: Angela Rayner, Labour’s deputy leader, raised further questions about her party’s pledge to invest £28 billion in green energy when she said it could not be bound by an “arbitrary number”.

value.name: ‘Abandoned by the Conservatives’ - insiders say Wellingborough Tory by-election campaign is struggling to attract top-level support
value.description: The Times asked ‘Where’s Helen’ in an eviscerating sketch after they visited Wellingborough. And the final insult was an astonishing piece written by Conservative Home, a website set up in support of the Tory party which offers news, analysis and comment on internal goings-on.

value.name: Tata Steel begins formal 45-day consultation over plans for Port Talbot plant
value.description: Tata Steel has started a formal 45-day consultation on its restructuring which is set to lead to thousands of job losses. The company is planning to shut down blast furnaces at its plant in Port Talbot, south Wales, and switch to a more environmentally friendly way of producing steel.

value.name: ‘No-one, especially the Tories, is laughing at us now,’ says Reform leader
value.description: In an interview with i, the Reform Party leader says his 'medium-term' plan to take the Tories' place as the threat from the right to Labour

value.name: Bomb explodes outside ministry in Athens, no injuries
value.description: An explosive device went off outside Greece's labour ministry in central Athens early on Saturday but caused no injuries, Greek police said. A Greek newspaper received a phone call by an unknown caller that a bomb had been planted at the ministry and had informed the police who cordoned off the area before the explosion which caused damage to the building and broken windows,

value.name: Hartlepool Council scraps plans to reduce CCTV coverage after new funding found
value.description: Hartlepool Council planned to reduce the hours CCTV coverage would be monitored but now this has been scrapped due to new funding.

value.name: New outdoor children's play park at Sunderland seafront could get the go ahead next week
value.description: Plans for a new children’s play area include a bridge, public walkways, landscaping and several “discrete play areas
